data.message: Hello TSP members! Many thanks to those of you who have done our first follow-up survey sent out two weeks ago. For those of you who haven't, don't forget to check your email and complete it for a $20 gift card! You’ll earn an additional $20 at the end if you fill out all surveys!
Hey TSP members! We apologize for the slight delay in sending out gift cards for your comments. We'll be sure to get them to you this week, so keep an eye on your inbox! Thanks for your patience :)
I got mine. $20. Not really worth it. I thought id at least get a physical card. Nope. Amazon. I dont even have an amazon account. Waste of time..
Apologies. It was definately worth it.

Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out last week. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!
Wait... There's another survey? I filled 1 out and already applied the electronic gift card for 20$... What's the other follow up survey- Tsp Study?
Hi 10349, this is just a reminder to do the survey from last week. It sounds like you've already done it - great! Thanks for the question.-Shirley from TSP

Hello TSP members! Yesterday’s post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email this week for our first follow-up survey. You will receive a $20 gift card upon completion.We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participation.Although we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.Again, from all of us at TSP, thank you and good luck in your future endeavors!

#90: Times they are a-changin’. Instead of endorsing smoking, Hollywood stars are now starting a new trend and quitting for their health. Check out this slideshow of all the actors and celebrities who have recently taken the dive and quit smoking! What do you think of this trend? #socialreflection
data.name: 10 Celebrities Who Quit Smoking
data.caption: www.shape.com
data.description: Cold turkey, hypnotism, electronic cessation...find out how 10 celebs kicked their smoking habit for good.

data.message: Good for them.

Well you know... Aside from not knowing who half these people are... I assume they are on this celebrity list for a reason. They a huge influence on people who follow pop culture some of them, religiously. So I think it's awesome! Good for them for doing so and promoting a healthy lifestyle.... But think about all the things celebrities do that influence peopl. I mean for fucks sake "Beleibers" were cutting themselves over something stupid. These... People, these celebrities have such a pull over people and most of them either don't care and let people blindly follow or do things that obviously influence followers. More celebrities need to model Emma Watson, she is using her influence for good! Others.. Eh. I think some try but fail horribly, and honestly it's our fault. We constantly poke into these people's lives and never give them a moment of privacy, imagine if someone was watching you every second of every day and exploiting everything you did... Yeah. Fuck that. We need to wake up people.
I believe some celebrities dont quit. They just dont smoke socially to keep their image up
Good for them and the people they influence
#89: Does hearing that rat poison is found in cigarettes change the way you feel about smoking? #beingconscious

I think we've already been asked this... And I'll say what I said on that. I think we are all aware of the chemicals that can be found in cigarette smoke. I think we are all between 18-25 right? DARE anyone? Yeah... We're no fools, and yet we continue to smoke.
No..
Nope, already knew.
Nope
Agreed. We know whats up with our ciggs.

#88: Your risk for stroke is now the same as a person who never smoked, your risk of lung cancer has dropped to half that of a continual smoker, and your risk of coronary disease and death in general have returned to nearly the level of people who have never smoked before. How do you feel knowing that you’re not doomed to have cancer? #beingconscious
We're all going to die, I think it's nice to have an idea as to how it will happen.

I find it hard to believe that after years smoking that quitting for 5 years will put my Risk at that of a non smoker ever... The damage we do is irreversible. But like 10374 said... We all die. It's inevitable.

'How do you feel knowing you're not doomed to have cancer?' Ok first of all not nearly everyone who smokes is going to get cancer. Secondly, there are plenty of people who don't smoke and still get cancer.
Well I guess I don't feel any way toward it. Considering I haven't quit.
My mom had it. So i feel if i get it at least i will know what'd she went through

#86: As a result of the 2009 Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act, tobacco companies have been banned from offering free samples and selling cigarettes in packages that contain fewer than 20 cigarettes. Why do you think that is? #beingconscious
Because if it's something free, it's easier to push someone to try it.
Exactly. Everyone loves free
It makes it harder to afford.

Ha! Really that sucks! I have ALWAYS wished they would sell like half sampler packs so you can find the brand you want... Oh wait that's what they are trying to prevent... Weird... It like they WANT the tobacco companies to make more money, so they can spend it on adverts, so they can gain new "clients" hmm....
The free samples is obvious, as for selling cigarettes in packs of 20 I don't really know
Wait... What the fuck is a "loose"? Haha
#87: Have you noticed more and more celebrities quitting smoking? Do you think this encourages more people to say goodbye to cigarettes? #socialreflection
I've never really noticed any celebrities smoking in the first place.

They are? Idk I don't keep up with pop culture... But I'm sure the grossly avid fans who follow their every move will be more likely to quit. It's a disgusting following that Hollywood has.... Hence why I don't do it.
I don't pay attention to celebrities so no.
Celebrities do it for the attention. Some to set an example. So yes. I do.
I haven't really heard about celebs quitting but I mean good for them and anyone they influence
I dont recall seeing how many posts we have commented on. I tried not to miss any but if i did and couldnt comment before this ends i will be mad.
#85: Have you ever heard this statistic before? How many smokers do you know? Divide that number by three and that’s how many may die in the future from a smoking-related illness. #beingconscious
I know Ann abundance of smokers so the math is impossible. But it does put into perspective how many fatalities with come to all of us
I've heard it and as true as it may be everyone is going to die eventually.

And 2 in three are going to die from a non-smoking related circumstance. And 100 percent of people who breathe air, drink water, or consume products are going to die. At least I've got an idea as to how it's likely to happen.
I've heard it before, we all die at some point
Never heard it before... Honestly.... Like I said on previous posts, like 10347 said above... We all die... Is a huge deal of how? No. Not really.

#84: Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have been more likely to start smoking as a minor if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig
I feel it would have happened either way, I'd just have enjoyed it more.

I do have to say those candy cigarettes were my faaaaaaaaavorite. Ever. They were bland and tasteless which made real cigarettes look and taste even better!  And I actually hate the taste of cigarettes... So flavoring them makes ME a legal smoker want to buy this stuff!
Agree with 10374!
I can imagine so. I enjoy the flavor of unflavored tobacco. I could only imagine what it would have been like to smoke something that tasted like something I favored.
I don't think so, when I started smoking it was because it was "cool", I think I would have thought that  candy flavoring was too childish
With the 90 days being almost over I am curious to hear about your experience: What is the most important thing you have learned from TSP? #TDII
That convincing someone to quit smoking and convincing someone to not smoke require vastly different methods, and the former seems much more difficult than the latter.
Hi 10374 - good to hear from you. So do you mean convincing someone to quit is much harder than convincing someone to not take it up in the first place?

Seems that way. Honestly this whole thing has felt less like a study and more like a campaign. Unless the study was to see how we would react to such strong bias coupled with fear tactics and other marketing techniques, in which case I feel that it has strengthened many of our resolve not to quit.
That's just based on what I've seen though.

That's very interesting 10374 and I appreciate your openness. I would also be curious what you think would be more effective to get people like yourself thinking about the pros and cons of smoking and quitting?

I think that if you honestly want to get people to quit smoking, it's not about making them think about the pros and cons, I haven't met a smoker who isn't completely aware of the pros and cons. I think it would be more effective to look at the situation from our point of view. Use empathy rather than sympathy. You have to, on an individual basis, create a common ground tied to the subject, and at least on a one on one level, bare within yourself a similar sort of weakness. It helps for it to be personal, which I think is the main reason it's so difficult.

Thank you for sharing this with me 10374! If I understand you correctly you're saying it's not about the pros and cons but about a truly personal connection and about understanding your point of view. What sort of content would be more relevant for you in this sort of study?

I'm not sure. I suppose that's part of the issue. Smoking doesn't seem to be as big of a deal for most of us as it seems to be for you guys. The biggest hurdle would be us not wanting to quit, and that's not something that you can force on someone. I would suggest making it seem like the smoker's idea to do so. A good way to do this, I think, would be more heavily supported statistics, facts, and evidence, and a focus on both the would be pros -and- cons. If it showed more that you recognize that we enjoy smoking, or whatever the case may be, and the things posted regular showed that that's taken into consideration, it would have had a greater effect on me. Instead, most of this has just felt impersonal and rife with bias, as though it's being preached from a pedestal rather than discussed on equal footing.

These are good suggestions 10374 and I appreciate your feedback! One thing I want to say though is that everything we post here is in fact supported by evidence, but I agree that we could post more content to back it up. On the other hand it's always a fine line and we obviously don't want to bother you guys with really long posts all the time. Again, thanks for your feedback!
I didn't mean to imply that there isn't evidence, I just meant that it would benefit from more evidence, and more easily accessed.

I honestly don't feel like I've learned anything... Some of the posts were awesome great pieces of discussion... Some of it also felt very attacking and propaganda. It's been an interesting and fun experiment.

#83: In movies and TV shows, smoking used to be a popular prop to make characters seem more edgy or cool. Researchers and even some members of Congress are urging Hollywood to cut out smoking images targeting youth. Do you think smoking in movies should mean they get a R-rating? Why? #beingconscious
I think the rating system in general is kinda stupid, so it's a moot point.

No that would be retarded. I agree with 10374- the movie rating system has evolved to allow more violence and language too a fro throughout the years... It's more based on the current socially acceptable norms and not on a single system that's not changing.  People who smoke in Hollywood have been... And forever will be edgy and cool.... There's no stopping it, so why spend my money to fight a battle you'll lose every. Single. Time. #ridiculous
Most kids now a days understand its bad for you but they can see it with out thinking they need to do it. So no. I do not believe so
No that's a little ridiculous. It's just going to make kids want to see those movies more. Plus it's not like they aren't going to walk outside and see someone smoking.

#82: One year after a cigarette, the additional risk of coronary heart disease accumulated while smoking has decreased by half. AND the health of your gums and teeth have improved drastically. What other changes in your life would be present after not smoking for 365 days? #beingconscious
I wouldn't smoke. That's the biggest one, really.
Other than those I don't really know
You wouldn't smell like a cigarette.
And chances are you'd be able to smell smoke a lot easier.
Im not sure how to answer this. More money? Obviously the previously stated but other then health benefits and money I'm not sure what else there is

I honestly can say I don't think my life would change any if I quit. I'd still do all the things I do now...smoking doesn't prevent me from doing things…Except working for AS. No one knows what the next year holds in store for any of us... Life could change drastically tomorrow... Or 364 days from now....

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Not Ready to Quit Yet 7.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #81: As far back as 1969, tobacco companies have said they have “taken a great many steps to avoid advertising directed to young people”, but 10 years later, they arranged for their cigarettes to be featured in The Muppet Movie. What do you think about tobacco companies targeting young people through the media? #beingconscious
I think theyre trying to connect to the parents. Not the kids

Even then, you're generalizing it as "tobacco companies". Despite the prevailing concept of big tobacco, there are separate companies in competition with each other, and you've provided no evidence that the company which did this ever said anything about avoiding that.
That would've been 30 years ago, when attitudes to cigarettes were different.

Honestly... I don't know... This may seem naïve but...advertisers are going to advertise to the group of people they think will purchase their product. As awful as it may sound...all advertisers are going  to do it, it's business. So, do I agree with it? Not necessarily, but I think anymore there are such restrictions on advertising anyway that it's harder to directly recognize- like 10358 said... This "statistic" is from the 70's.
I don't really think it matters. People are going to do what they want regardless.

#80: It’s true, all the new tobacco legislation sure is making it harder to smoke. But have you ever turned it on its head? How is this new legislation making it easier for you to quit? What new laws or regulations would be really helpful to you if you decided to stop smoking? #socialreflection

I can honestly say- maybe just because I'm ridiculously stubborn- but the more some tells me I can't do something the more I am bound and determined to do it. So if you tell me it's harder to smoke- I'll find a way to smoke anyone anywhere.  Is it making it easier to quit? No- it's makes me not want to quit more.
Didn't we just all pretty much say the laws haven't really been affecting us in a post a few days ago?

My smoking habit is a personal issue, and the absolutely LAST thing I want is a government organization influencing my personal choices in what I consume. Substances and consumables should only be illegal if their effects immediately endanger the community at large. It is my right to do what I like with my body, no matter how detrimental, so long as I don't hurt others. Laws to help prevent second hand smoke are fine, but if I'm not physically endangering or hurting others I don't want the law getting anywhere near my personal choice to quit, should I make it.
No laws are effecting the way i smoke
Thanks for sharing your thoughts!

#77: Anyone who smokes knows someone who wants them to quit. Think about the people in your life who want you to quit: why do they want this so badly for you? What types of arguments do they have? #socialreflection
The only reason the ONE person i know that wants to quit gave me was it was too expensive. They bought the ecigg to quit but ended up continuing to smoke
I don't really have anyone like that.
I only have my parents, they tell me about how unhealthy it is
Health reasons. There arguments are the health reasons.
My dad REALLY wants me to quit. He is a former smoker and my grandfather, his dad, died of cancer due to smoking.
Thanks for sharing!

#76: Every year it seems like there’s a new bill or law passed that’s tightening up the smoking legislation. What recent changes to tobacco laws in your community are making it harder for you to smoke? Do you think these new laws protect more people than they inconvenience? #socialreflection
None of them affect me or make it harder to smoke.

Honestly I haven't seen or heard of any changes in Colorado in recent years.... The last initiative I heard was several years ago- no smoking 30 ft from a public entrance- however that's almost NEVER enforced. Also I smoke in my car  and work (on breaks) most often so... They can't tell me not to smoke in my car. Haha so I personally think they are inconveniencing everyone with silly petty laws almost no one enforces. Why? Law makers are wasting their time and our money on these laws.

I haven't run into issues either. Being a relatively low rank in the military, I have to live on base and thus already deal with fairly tight smoking restrictions, such as only being allowed to smoke at designated areas, but I can live with that.
Just more no smoking areas i suppose
I haven't had any issues, most anti smoking laws I agree with (to an extent)
Thanks for discussing your experience!
#79: Coughing, sinus congestion, fatigue, and shortness of breath all decrease after this long without a cigarette. What can you do with a clear airway that you can’t do now? #beingconscious
I haven't noticed any issues like that, so I don't know. Likely not much. That or I naturally have super human lung capacity, and smoking brings it down to normal levels.
I havent noticed any issues either
I'm not quite sure.
The only one of these I've noticed is shortness of breath, and it really doesn't effect me to much. I actually went on a 5 mile hike earlier today no problem.
I can do anything now- vs 9 months from now...?
#78: Why might your smoking buddies want you to keep smoking? What are their motives? #socialreflection
I don't really know of anybody who particularly wants me to keep smoking, nor wants me to stop. It's really usually just a neutral point.
Even though my friend group does mostly consist of other smokers, no one really WANTS me to keep smoking. Whenever one of us quits we actually support and praise them.
If I wanted to quit they wouldn't be dicks. They are my friends and they love and support me. If your smoking buddies don't support you... They aren't your friends and fuck them for real though.
Everyone feels like its my choice. This question makes it sound like people are forcing me. When that has never been the case.
How would you support a friend who wants to quit smoking? #TDII
I'm not even sure. I know I wouldn't smoke around them.
Hi 10336 - that's a great suggestion. And how would you want others to support YOU, if you were ever ready to quit? What could they do?
Just don't smoke around me. And don't say anything about it to me.
What do you mean by "don't say anything about it", 10336?
I mean my friends. If you want to help me don't talk about it around me.
Ok, I understand. You don't want your friends to talk about smoking to you. What could they say that would be helpful, if anything?
I couldn't care less if they said something right now I know I'm not going to quit anytime soon.
But nothing. They couldn't say anything.
Haha, ok. No, I'm still talking about a hypothetical scenario if you were ever ready. Why couldn't they say anything?
Because I just don't care what people say.

I see 10336. It's going to be you who makes the decision  about smoking or not-smoking and also you who is going to pull through with it, no matter what others think or say. That's great and I encourage you to go your own way and make the decisions that are best for you.
Support them, not smoke around them/and or offer them a smoke... That's like a major dick move.
I wouldn't smoke around them

#75: FACT: Treatments cost between $3-$10/day, and some health insurances cover medications and/or counseling. Would you spend a little more money to finally stop throwing cash down that bottomless cigarette-pit? Why do you think so many smokers don’t? #beingconscious
I feel like the cheap methods of quitting have been unsuccessful more then successful
If I wanted to quit I could without having to use any sort of treatments, I just don't want to.

I would stop spending money on cigarettes to spending the same of not more on counseling every week for the rest of my life? #nothanks  *personal opinion* counseling is bullshit, they give you pills and tell you things so that THEY have created a lifelong customer. In my mind counsellors and "therapy" is no better than Tobacco Companies.
I will if I have to, but I think for some it doesn't work, and for others it may be a matter of pride.
Also what 10349 said is a very real probability, I think.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts!
#74: When you're online, how is smoking portrayed on your favorite sites such as Facebook or YouTube? What messages are being sent online about smoking? #socialreflection
None that I really notice.
*time
2nd that. This page is the first in a looooong tome
It's not. It has like a .000000003% presence on social Media. All of that percentage, I've found.... On this page.  People don't care/don't talk about it openly on social medias.
Not much, I think, but I haven't been looking.
I don't ever see anything
Thanks for sharing!
#70: Check out what Big Tobacco companies consider their 'Doomsday Scenario'. What do you think about what their records say? #socialreflection

It's business. It's them being honest about what makes their money, and what will cause them to make much less of it. More a product of a capitalistic society than the product of anything to do with smoking.
I agree ^ couldn't say it better
I need sources before I believe this. And even if it's true, no business wants to run out of customers.
I think it's them being honest...? Pretty much what  10374 already said. It's business....
Its a company full of people trying to make a living.
That does seem kinda bad but what 10374 said. That's capitalism for you.
Thanks for sharing!

#69: Check out this link to view which U.S. College Campuses and Universities have 100% Smoke-Free ordinances. Do you think it’s a good idea to make institutions of higher education smoke free? #socialreflection
data.name: pdf/smokefreecollegesuniversities.pdf
data.caption: no-smoke.org

data.message: I think they should have smoke pits, designated smoking areas so the non-smokers don't have to interact with smoking people, with no smoking everywhere else. I've been living on military installations for the past two years, and it works well enough here.

I kinda think it's stupid.  Like... Why? If you don't like that I'm smoking around you... Go away. It's like saying lets have a bike free campus because I don't like bikes buzzing around me.  Plus- I'll smoke where I want anyway.....

I think the idea is just a matter of population. If there's nobody around, light up. But it's just a dick move to make others deal with your choice to smoke, and in a heavily populated place like that, there's not always somewhere for them to comfortably leave to.
I believe there should be smoking sections at every public place. ( i understand not indoors ) its a persons choice whether they want to smoke or not

On some level I totally agree! And idk I think situationally it's all relevant.... I personally would excuse myself from a group of people, dependent on size of the group... If it's 1-5 whatever I don't care, especially if it's outside. Like..... Walk away. It's also not like I'm gonna walk up to a group of people and blow smoke in their face either. But- example--- when I was visiting college campuses... It was a non smoking campus and as I was walking around I was technically "off campus" grounds and at a cross walk smoking and a group of people came up - obviously non smokers- and they just kept their distance from the smell as I made an effort as well to not move closer- or blow smoke in their direction. I think smokers yes need to be conscious of others... But at the same time....non smokers can respect our choice to smoke, outside where permitted or where there is not a smoking restriction anyway.

I can see having a mostly smoke free campus. My college is smoke free and they charge a hefty fine if you get caught smoking, even if you're in your own vehicle in the parking lot. I don't mind not being able to smoke in the common space, but I think it's utter crap to penalize somebody for smoking in their own property when they're away from almost everyone else.

My campus is smoke free but lots of people still smoke, only now we don't have ashtrays so a lot of people just leave their butts wherever. The only thing being a "smoke free" campus has done is piss people off and made the whole place trashier. Having designated smoking areas would make a lot more sense.
I agree the college I plan on going to has ash trays in front of most of the buildings which I think is great
I'm almost positive close to all schools do and it makes sense.
Great points! Thanks for discussing, everyone! :)

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Not Ready to Quit Yet 7.

data.description: Hi guys, the next Q&A session will be tomorrow. See you then!

data.message: #73: Have you noticed how smoking is portrayed in magazines and advertisements? How do you feel about the way it's represented to the world? #socialreflection

I feel that for the most part it's not. Most cigarette advertising has been stamped out, from what I've seen. I definitely see more non-smoking ads. I already smoke, and as I feel it's the responsibility of the consumer to understand what they're buying and the risks associated, it's mostly inconsequential to me.
These magazines all look like they're from 50s. It's really not seen at all today.
It really means nothing to me.

Honestly.... I have never seen an ad for smoking in a magazine.... Or on TV. Or on the radio.... I was born in the early 90's long after the major buzz for smoking... And by the time I was at an age to be seeing adverts... Like 10374 said they had all been stamped out. Sooooo... There's that.

First of all, 3/4 of these advertisements are vintage as fuck, and would never make it into today's publications. Secondly, those Newport smokers look like any other person who's having a good time. They do the same with soda ads.
Smoking is portrayed badly. I feel smoking is bad but it is a persons choice.as long as its their informed
#72: Lots of people are bothered by the strong smell of nail polish remover, but did you know that anyone who smokes a cigarette is inhaling this chemical into their lungs? #beingconscious
I didnt know that, but nail polish remover smell doesnt bother me either
I know and don't care.

To be perfectly honest.... Nail polish remover is one of my favorite smells.... And so is "disk cleaner"  kinda gross I inhale a vapor... But I think we all know there are chemicals in cigarettes.... I present a question I've always been curious about though..... In 'additive free' cigarettes... Is that just plain- straight up tobacco? Or do those even have chemicals such as acetone in them? Tsp Study I'd like to know!  Thanks!
Yup.
I've been taught about all the nasty chemicals in cigarettes since I was in 7th grade. I just don't care.
#71: How is smoking portrayed on TV? What have you noticed about characters who smoke on TV shows or in movies? #socialreflection
I barely see people who smoke on tv but when i do its when theyre stressed

I really think how it's portrayed depends on what kind of programming you watch... Any "family" or kid stuff aaaaaaaaalways has a negative connotation and blah blah blah or the "bad boy" kind of rep... Where as more dramatic "adult" type shows its just a thing... Like how it is in real life.
I feel like it depends on what you watch.
To me, I don't see it too often, but when I do it seems to be used to signify that someone is under a lot of stress.
It's really not seen that often any more
How does your smoking affect your loved ones, kids, or significant other? What do they think about your smoking? #TDII
My sig other smokes. And i dont have kids
Thanks for sharing 10347! Did anyone you are close to ever nag you about your smoking? If so what reasons did they give you?
It doesn't affect them... Aside from them just not wanting me to for health reasons. And they are just concerned with the health aspect of smoking. But it's not something they blatantly express.
Hi 10349 - and what do you think about their concerns?

My mom has always been very concerned about my smoking, though it only directly affects her when I smoke around her. I also think that the main reason my boyfriend started smoking again is because I smoke.
I validate them and move on with my life. I'll quit smoking if/when I want.
Hi 10353! How do you feel about your Mom's concerns and about your boyfriend starting to smoke again?
10349 - I agree with you: No one can make that decision for you and you have to decide when you are ready to quit!

I understand my mom's concerns, and she makes valid points, but they're not enough to make me quit. I feel worse about influencing my boyfriend, but he smoked for many years before he ever met me, and he's an adult so he can make his own decisions.
Exactly! I appreciate their concerned, it reminds me I'm loved... But it's also my decision... So.

10353 - yes. Others' concern can maybe get us thinking but it likely won't be enough to makes us change our behavior if we don't want to do it ourselves. I remember you were somewhat concerned about some health consequences of smoking you witnessed last week. What additional thoughts about smoking have you had since we last spoke?
Frankly, I haven't really had any new revelations. I also haven't taken any steps towards quitting, even though I still freaked out about what happened last week.

I think you'll know when you are ready to take these steps 10353. Sometimes an event like the one you experienced can make us evaluate our choices and give us a new and somewhat different perspective on things.
I don't get to interact with them in person, because of the military.
Hi 10374 - do you know how they feel about you smoking?
My mom doesn't like it, but won't chide or judge me for it because it would be hypocritical, as she's also a smoker. Pretty much everybody else I know doesn't care one way or the other.
I see 10374. What does your mom not like about it?
I imagine the health risks. At the same time, she respects my choice, and that it is my choice. I still somewhat casually try to avoid making her think about it, as she is quitting.
It's nice of her to be respectful of your choice! Sounds like she is really trying to make a change in her life. Does that influence how you think about your own smoking 10374?
Also, what would be some other things you could do to support her 10374?
Sorry I've got to run. See you next week.
My dad gets annoyed because he doesn't like the smell, my mom takes my cigarettes when she runs out and nobody else really cares.
Johannes Thrul no one has ever nagged me. My dad did want me to not smoke at my grandfathers house out pf respect for him though

#68: Many people don’t like to label themselves as a “smoker”. The fact remains that switching to an e-cig does not mean you’ve stopped ingesting addictive and harmful chemicals. And Big Tobacco would much rather you switch and remain a loyal customer, than deciding to quit once and for all. Have you ever felt like you had to hide your smoking? #ecig
you've already asked us this but no I've never had to hide smoking
Only back when I wasn't supposed to be smoking.
No
10374 said it. Haha only when I was like 12-17 after that... I'm an adult. I make my own decisions and choices and I don't hide who I am. I try to be my authentic self all the time.
No
When I was under 18, other than that no

#67: Your overall blood circulation has improved, walking has become easier, and your lung function has increased significantly. Have you noticed anything physical becoming more difficult as you smoke more? #beingconscious

Uhh.... Not really....I've always been fat so... Everything as always put me out of breath. Haha I've never noticed it with more or less smoking- I mean unless I smoke a pack in like 1 night then the next day I'll feel a little out of it. But aside from that... Nope.
No.. Not at all.
Not really, no.
Ive always had trouble with physical activities. My asthma is what makes them hard not smoking
I have never had any trouble physically even with smoking
I only notice when I go swimming.
Sometimes when I run

#66: Check out this link to see what the Tobacco Control Laws are like in your state. Be sure to know the smoking legislation if you plan on traveling. What do you think about the laws in your state? #socialreflection

data.message: I'm fine with the laws in my state
They don't seem unreasonable.
idk if its just my computer/phone...but i cannot access the map, ive tried 2 computers and my phone and it wont work.....
The laws have never affected me. I'm fine with them
I'm perfectly fine with them. They are decently fair.
I don't have a problem with the laws in my state. I only worry about them when I visit California anyway.
I'm fine with them

data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #65: Have you noticed your sense of smell being impacted by your smoking? What different kinds of scents have you missed since you started smoking? #beingconscious
No I haven't.
I have slightly, but I'm pretty okay with it. It helps cut down on the gross smells too!
Ok really Tsp Study.... Haha you literally asked this question already... And I'll say it. Yes I have but its not a huge deal. Like 10353 id rather NOT smell some things too...
My nose is very sensitive. But. I havent noticed any lack of smell
None, really.
I have not
I naturally have a pretty darn good sense of smell and I haven't noticed any difference at all in what I can smell.

#64: Why do you think romantic partners have such a big impact on how much you smoke? If you’re in a relationship, what could your partner do to help you change your ways, and if not, would you be willing to quit smoking to begin a new relationship? #beingconscious
I'm not really going to quit smoking if someone wants me too if they love me they can deal with it to and my wife used to smoke but she stopped when she got pregnant
Don't have one.
If i decided to quit my boyfriend would quit with me
I'm not too sure but I do know that I'm not too worried about it. Most people I know smoke.
I'm with 10347. If I was going to quit (or my boyfriend wanted to try again), I think we would be more successful if we did it together.
I don't have a partner really, and if I did I probably wouldn't change my habits for them.
#63: What would you do with those 18 days -- go on a trip? Stay home and finally watch that movie everyone’s been talking about? #beingconscious
Probably nothing. As a smoker I'm still going to go on trips and watch movies.
We also spend years on the toilet. Those 18 days aren't consecutive so it really wouldn't make much of a ddifference.

I agree with 10336... I'm still going on trips.. Hi. I'm a travel agent. And all I do when I'm home alone is watch movies soooooo... Yeah. It would make no difference- as well it's not as if we get those 18 days in a lump sum... It's small... 5-15 minutes increments throughout the day. Soooo..... Yes.
If i was off for 18 days and i had money id go on a trip. But if i didnt . i dont think id enjoy spending 18 days sitting at home. Ill take my smoke breaks
Probably divide them up throughout my work days and take them as smoke breaks.
I'd copy 10374
So much apathy. Hahaha. I love it. I'd take a brewery tour of the US, and make ample time for smoke breaks to accrue time for my next vacation!
What would you miss most if you quit smoking for good? #TDII
The whole act of smoking.
And what is it about the act of smoking you like 10353?
The way the smoke tastes, how it makes me feel, how much cooler I look when I do it, and the chance to take a break and just think about things while I do it.
Thanks for sharing! What other things would you miss?
I think I just about summed it up. Though I guess I'd also having something to distract me when things aren't going well.
You really have many things you would miss 10353 - the taste, coolness, the brakes and distraction it gives you. What are the things you would be happy to get rid of if you ever quit?
The health risks and the loss of money.
What health risks are you most concerned about? How much money do you usually spend on cigarettes each week 10353?

I don't want to get COPD or emphysema or anything like that. I don't want to have a tracheotomy either. I work for a man who has severe breathing issues from smoking, and after an episode today I'm a little scared about it. My spending on cigarettes depends on the week, but anywhere between 28 to 42 dollars a week. I have expensive taste.
Thanks for sharing 10353! I always thought health would be less of a concern for you. What was different about your experience today?
Probably nothing?
You wouldn't miss anything about smoking 10349?

It usually was, but then it dawned on me that I likely wouldn't die from any complications, I'd just be forced to live with them in misery. I'm not at liberty to discuss details, but that's what I observed today with my client.
No need to discuss details 10353, I think I know what you mean. How does that change the way you think about smoking or quitting (if it does at all)?

It makes me think that I should quit if I don't want to end up in the same state. It also makes me question myself, since I was always so steadfastly in favor of smoking. My client still smokes, despite his situation, and I fear that I might be in his position of I'm not careful.
That does sound like an intense experience 10353. You say if you are not careful you could end up in the same situation as your client. What could you do to be more careful?
Quit smoking immediately! That's the most relevant factor. Getting more exercise couldn't hurt either.
If you seriously consider quitting, how would you go about it 10353?
I'd stop buying cigarettes, and stop going outside when my loved ones smoke. I'd likely attend the smoking cessation classes they offer at my local hospital.

All of these sound like great strategies 10353! If you are seriously considering quitting these are the 5 things that are most important in my experience: 1. I would recommend to pick a quit day and following through with it. 2. Get support from family/friends/colleagues. 3. Learn new skills and alternative behaviors for your high risk situations. 4. Depending on how much you smoke, I would definitely recommend that you consider trying some form of nicotine replacement therapy – we know that using these can dramatically decrease your cravings and withdrawal and increase your chances to quit for good. 5. Be prepared for relapse or difficult situations (e.g., alcohol, being around other smokers, stress, etc.).  How does this sound? Anything there you think may be useful?
I've got to run. Good talking to you today! See you next week.
Also check out these pros and cons to smoking and quitting. See you.
Johannes... Nope. Haha I hate smoking and I tell people to never pick up cigarettes.
62. On average, smokers get sick more often than nonsmokers. How would work or school be different if you didn’t smoke? #beingconscious
Work without smokes would suck, frankly.
I don't get sick too often at all, if anything I'd just get more stressed with out cigs and get sick from that
I'm rarely sick. So out would not be any different

Actually, I don't get sick nearly as often as I used to. I take online classes, and I go to work unless I'm vomiting or have explosive diarrhea because frankly, that's the only time that you're actually required to call in to work.
I hardly ever get sick so I'm v fine and it wouldn't be any different

I don't think I get sick anymore than anyone else....I've been sick 2 times this year... Some coworkers have been sick 3 or more times this year... And none of them smoke. So... I mean I understand smoking depletes your immune system to a point... But unless you're going around licking things and people... And aren't disgusting and wash your hands and body regularly... I don't think you'll get sick more then anyone else... Work would suck without cigarettes. Haha
I hardly get sick so they only thing that would change is my smoke breaks.
60. Who in your life would benefit if you decided to quit smoking? Think of all the people your smoking touches and comment on each other’s lists. #smokingaffectsall
Me, I would benefit the absolute most.
Me as well
Me mostly
My niece.
My mom.
I guess sort of my parents

I agree with the first three posts. I suppose my mom would, because she doesn't smoke and she hates it when I smoke around her. My brother and boyfriend might, since they do smoke and might get motivated to quit if I was there with them.

61. Since President Obama signed the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act into law, tobacco companies have been banned from brand sponsorship of sports and entertainment events. Do you think the fans at these events will miss their favorite Tobacco brands at their game or show? #socialreflection

Yes. When i go to an outdoor event i feel i should be able to. Even if it means being in the smoking section. But banning it all together is not right. Some sporting events have some dull times, its noce to be able to have a cigarette during that time
I wouldn't but I don't know about everyone else

I don't think that people would miss the sponsorship aspect. Almost everyone knows that it's hard to be a successful athlete if you  smoke. But if they want to ban smoking at these venues, that's bogus.
I absolutely don't care. Not one for sports, really.
You know I doubt they noticed before... So no. Granted... I don't watch sports so I've personally never noticed it.

data.message: 32. Children can’t really distinguish between vapor and smoke. What they do see is important adults in their life setting an example for how to take care of themselves, what they spend their money on, and their attitudes about addictive substances. Would you hide your e-cig smoking from a child? #ecig

No. It is the parents responsibility to educate the child, not through a fear campaign or a do as I say not as I do attitude, but through providing facts and reasoning, and answering the child's questions honestly and thoroughly. Not hiding it from them.
I agree that honesty and transparency with your children is a great policy. -kat from tsp
no I wouldn't it would be best to let them know and expose the truth
Nope. I wouldn't be smoking an e-cigarette either.
Education is key. Not hiding things

If I am still smoking when I have kids- I won't lie to them. I'll be very upfront and not hide it from them, and I'll let them know why daddy always smells weird or why he can't play- however like I said on one of the earliest posts- when I have kids the cigarettes go!

I wouldn't go out of my way to hide smoking a regular or an e cigarette; that being said, I wouldn't do it around them, and I would try my best to make sure they're educated about all the negative consequences of either (and smokeless tobacco as well, even though I don't use it.)
I would do what my aunt did, hide it completely when I was little, but as I got older and was able to comprehend that cigarettes are bad she made less of an effort

47. Your chance of a heart attack has already decreased after only one day without a cigarette. Your body will thank you. What do you usually think of when considering being smoke free for a full day? #beingconscious
If I'm smoke free for an entire day I'm probably thinking about how sick I am (that's the only time I ever go a whole day without a cigarette).
I don't usually try to be smoke free. But if i was it would be because i was working and didnt have timw

You know honestly it didn't even phase me.... I was this past weekend. At my family reunion, I smoked a cigarette at about 2330 on Friday and didn't have one until about 1800 on Sunday evening. Smoking didn't even cross my mind as I was hanging out with my 2 year old niece the whole time- her clinging to me like a little monkey.... I was thinking about how I can't wait for her to grow up and I can be her cool guncle... Ha smoking isn't a necessity to me.
The last time I went that long without a cigarette I was hospitalized and I could not wait to get out and light a cigarette.
how irritated I'll be when I'm out of smokes
How grumpy I'll be

58. Because your nerve endings have started to re-grow, your ability to smell and taste is enhanced. How much better does everything taste when you don’t smoke? Do you miss any of your favorite dishes? #beingconscious
The only time i notice a difference is right after i smoke. And i smoke after i eat not before
I've been told about this but I never notice any difference in my taste and smell when I haven't smoked for a few days
You know I actually have noticed this. When I was clean for a couple months I could taste eeeevvveeerrrryyything. But idk honestly it all tastes the same.. If that makes sense haha
I don't really notice a difference at all.
I don't really notice it.
I never notice, again because I only ever don't smoke when I'm sick, so taste and smells are diminished anyway.
no I don't notice

59. FACT: Research shows that although some people quit cold turkey successfully, the most effective way to quit smoking is using a combo of counseling plus nicotine replacement therapy (NRT’s, like patch or gum) or medicine (like bupropion SR). What have you heard about NRT’s? Would you consider using them? #beingconscious
I would.

I was actually on bupropion for a bit and it made smoking significantly less pleasurable, but I still craved cigarettes. It kinda sucked. Also a big part of smoking for me isn't the nicotine but the just the habit of it
These questions are getting very redundant. I don't like reruns. But again, I wouldn't bother with NRTs because it's just a crutch.
I agree with 10353- on all aspects. I've quit cold turkey before, and I'll do it again if I want to. Haha
I probably would
I have not thought about it but probably
57. How do you think your life would change if you always smelled fresh and never like a cigarette? #balance
Rude. I go to lengths to ensure I do not smell like cigarettes, so the only difference is I would be a much angrier person who doesn't smoke.
I don't see how it would be any different
Didn't we already have a question super similar to this?I never smell "like an ashtray"
Nothing would change. That's totally superficial anyway.

I literally just smelled my ashtray. And it honestly doesnt smell bad. HaIfies smell worse. dont think thats an accurate description of the way a smoker smells. But the smell has never bothered me so my mindset wouldnt change. If anything i might feel a little less at ease. The smell of cigarettes is a comfort to me because my mom smoked.
Psh- girl I always smell freshhhhh No but for real. I always smell good. Like I said in a previous post- people don't know I smoke for a long time cause I never smell like cigarettes.
10358- I feel like they've started to  repetitively ask us questions... This isn't the first time... Weird.
10349, they are getting really repetitive! They're just trying to wear us down. Haha.
Haha I know! Like the "doctor" guy- literally asked us the Saaaame Question from weeks ago. What??
Maybe they're running out of new ideas. Hopefully things will get interesting again soon.
56. The Wanted's band member Max George is photographed smoking all the time. How do you think this is influencing his fans’ ideas about tobacco? #beingconscious
I doubt that it makes much of a difference.
I don't know who he his, and don't really care.
I don't know who that is and I don't think it would have that much of an influence
It more than likely does absolutely nothing.
Who? I've never heard of this band. Regardless his fans probably think he's a smoker.  They probably think it's cool and hot and whatever else fan girls think about?
First comment. No difference. Most people don't care what others are doing with their lives

55. Hey ladies, did you know that quitting smoking can reduce the chances of ectopic pregnancy, miscarriage, still birth, and having a low birth weight baby? What do you think about this? Guys, how does knowing this make you feel about encouraging the women you love to quit smoking? #beingconscious
I think most people know this, and most women quit smoking during pregnancy.

That hits home because I did have an ectopic pregnancy and if I could go back and change absolutely anything to deliver a healthy baby I would. I never got the chance to know I was pregnant and quit smoking before I knew it I was in the hospital with an IV talking to surgeons.
Whoa. #60'sthrowback? Who smokes while pregnant? I think the whole damn world has been briefed on this by now... If not. Bad parent.  If you do, bad parent.
Well my "wife" won't have to worry about smoking while pregnant... Cause my wife will have a penis.
Im going to quit before i have a baby
Yeah I'm pretty sure most people know about that, and I'm definitely going to quit before I have kids.
no different really I am due to be a father and I believe that if you don't speak a symptom over someone then it doesn't happen

Yeah, that's kind of common knowledge. I don't want to have children, and I do everything in my power to avoid pregnancy. Of I ever did decide to have a baby, I'd probably quit. I just hope that doesn't happen.
Today, I wanted to ask you about smoking and alcohol use. Is there a connection between the two in your personal experience? #TDII
I think there is to an extent. Of course I smoke anyway, but I seem to smoke a lot more when I've been drinking.
You guys have already asked us this question......
Thanks for sharing 10353! Why do you think it is that smoking and drinking go together for you?

My bad habits love each other as much as I love them.To be honest, I couldn't tell you exactly what it is that makes me smoke more while drinking, just that cigarettes seem to taste extra delicious after a few beers.
Hi 10349 - thanks for the reminder :)

Well I will reiterate what I said then as it still applies 100% so...Ohhhhh laaawwwdddd I can easily smoke 2+ packs in one night if I'm heavily drinking hahaha how could I stop? Uhh... Just.... not I guess?  Haha it would be really hard though... Especially in an inebriated state? That's a toughy!!

10353 - why smoking and alcohol go together so well is still a hot research question. Probably has to do with a chemical interaction between both substances. But the social context may also have to do with it, since not many young adults drink without friends. So guys, let me ask you this: It seems like situations with alcohol are really high risk for smoking. If you ever wanted to change your smoking what would you do in these situations 10353 10349?
Avoid those types of situations! Or chew on straws instead of smoking cigarettes. But frankly, I don't see that happening.

No worries, I'm not pushing you to make it happen when you are not ready for it 10353 - that's entirely your decision. Maybe you will be one day and these strategies may come in handy. How successful do you think they will be if you put them to the test?

Avoiding the situation would probably be very unsuccessful. But chewing on straws actually works because it keeps your mouth and your hands busy, like a cigarette. In sure it can't be that good for you though.

That sounds like a good strategy 10353! I wouldn't be too worried about the health effects of chewing straws :) Keeping hands and mouth busy by using alternatives is something many people do when they try to quit or reduce smoking. Some other ideas you could try just for fun: Keep your hands busy: Use a stress ball, play a game on your phone, play with a Rubik’s cube, start a fun arts and crafts project. Keep your mouth busy: Use gum, hard candy, mints, chew on toothpicks, prepare healthy snacks like veggie sticks, drink plenty of water.
I'm sure there is a connection. Not so much in my life though.

54. Quitting smoking can slow balding in men. Fellas, does this seem like a good reason to think about quitting? And ladies, how would this fact help you encourage your male loved ones to quit smoking?  #beingconscious
Actually, this is one of the few things that -almost- motivates me to quit, the other being my voice. I enjoy acting, and less hair = more typecasting, which is just the truth.
I don't even know. It seems like the thing I would be least concerned with.

I'm not really concerned with it. Baldness runs in my family, and my brother's hair was already thinking before he started smoking. My boyfriend shaves his head anyway, so it wouldn't make much of a difference to me there either.
I'm not going to convince any one of any life decisions. My man can do whatever he pleases.
I'm not really concerned with it, I'm not a male and even if I was compared to all the other problems smoking causes it would be one of the least of my worries.
I don't care I'm going to get old and die no matter what

Mmmmmm... I don't believe this is a thing. Haha nope. I don't buy it.... I'm pretty sure that's determined by... Genetics? Yeah. Soooo I have to dismiss this post as malarkey.  However- if there were any truth to it- I ain't worried. I'm doomed for baldness (from genetics...)  anyway... So. Whatever...  once it starts in just gonna shave it.
#nohairdontcare
51. Why do you think hookah has held on to a "cool" reputation even though it's just as unhealthy as other forms of tobacco use? #beingconscious
I'm not even completely sure what a hookah is.
Its a more leisurely activity. Because of the amount of upkeep and time it takes to set up, people use it as a treat if you wanna call it that. Cant take your hookah to work and smoke it lmao.

Exactly, it's a once in a while thing, with even more connotations than cigarettes as a social thing. Even though smoking hookah for one hour is like 200 cigarettes, the average smoker will smoke easily over 200 cigarettes before someone who only smokes hookah does it again. It's the infrequency that makes it seem healthier.

hmm.....well whatever i suppose, I love hookah. Love love love love it. the taste the feel the everything! why is it still cool or whatever... well 10347 literally stole the words from my mouth. Leisure activity- not a day to day thing...unless your'e me... :0)
I agree with everyone else, and also there are not many people who will straight do nothing but smoke hookah for an hour. Eventually you start to feel kinda sick.
10349 even if its a day to day thing im sure you still feel the need for a cigg after, i know i do
First thing I do once I either leave the lounge or clean up! Haha
Right

I also agree with the previous posts. I feel like smoking a hookah is a more intimate social activity too. You can smoke a cigarette with anyone, but I feel like you would only invite people who you're really close with to share a hookah with you.

53. While ammonia helps keep our bathrooms and kitchens clean, it does anything but that for our lungs. Does learning it's found in cigarettes change the way you think or feel about smoking? #beingconscious
Already knew.
Makes me feel a little torn up but still the same
I already know that and it doesn't change that for me
I didn't know that, but it changes nothing.

I feel that maybe most of us still smoke because health threats, gross factor, and scare tactics are not effective methods of propaganda towards us. I wouldn't expect to see many different responses to this question. I don't know what sort of target audience this works on, but it doesn't seem to be us.
I already knew, and completely agree with 10374

Nope. I love the way ammonia, jet fuel, and animal feces taste and feel in my lungs. I've been well informed of all the toxic crap they put in cigarettes since I started smoking, and I've continued to do it anyway. I guess I'm just a hardass.

It won't let me use the calculator..
I also can't use the calculator

50. FACT: People usually take two or three attempts to successfully quit for good. Aaliyah said it best: If at first you don't succeed, Dust yourself off and try again. Would you be able to try again? #beingconscious
Anybody can try but it takes someone who really wants it to actually quit.
If I wanted to, yeah.

If it came down to really wanting to for my own personal benefit, yes. So far I've only tried to quit because it's what I'm "supposed" to do, and that doesn't work. But if I finally resolved to do it for myself, I would try again.
Yes because the only reason I'd quit is because i had to

Of course I would try again. What a ridiculous question. If you and your spouse are trying to have a baby and you don't get pregnant the first time- would you stop having sex? And say "oh well- wasnt meant to be." No! If you are looking for a job and get turned down by the first place you apply, do you stop putting in applications and going to interviews? NO! This is an absurd question that I don't think it's based in any type of reality.
You tell 'em 10349!
Haha I am ON ONE TODAY!!! Damn airlines get me all riled up!!! Haha
Hahaha, frustration comes standard with every flight!
Maybe I don't
Yeah definitely

49. Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately, studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or Nicotine Replacement Therapy (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit. #ecig
I figured that was obvious..
I  see I think it works because my mother no longer smokes
My friend actually was able to quit be switching to first ecigs then vaping and now he's totally nicotine free
I've never met anyone who's quit by switching to ecigs in fact of all my smoking friends it makes them crave paper cigarettes even more... So..... Duh? Haha
I know a few people who switched, but I don't consider that quitting.
I know a couple people who have used ecigs to quit smoking
The only person I know who was using an e-cig to quit is my boyfriend. He recently started smoking paper cigarettes again, so I'd say that they're kind of bogus.
great thread guys! thanks for sharing

48. For any of you that aren’t sure what an e-cig is, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulations. Do you feel that if you were a minor, an e-cig would be more appealing and seem “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #ecig
I do see the truth in it being more appealing to minors
Personally, I've never found ecigs appealing. They're more expensive and the vapor doesn't look as cool as smoke does. Vapes are cool enough though.
Yes but mostly because it would be easier to hide from parents

Hmm..... When I was a young'n my best friends parents had like one of the first e-cigarettes. We thought it was the coolest shit ever!!! We played with them, and even puffed on them... Even though we were maybe.... 10-11 years old. I absolutely see the appeal for young people as - and especially in this day and age- we are all about the next best thing! Bigger! Shinier! More electronically driven than ever, our society has almost everything driven toward- new and more advanced than ever! Conversely, at the time even I know what it was... I knew it was still just like smoking a cigarette. The thought never crossed my mind "oh yeah! This is much 'safer' than smoking a paper cigarette!" No I wasn't an idiot... Can I say the same for the you see generations?  no.

I'm sure to a minor an electronic cigarette sounds pretty awesome. It is decently odorless so nobody would ever guess it is nicotine and they can smoke them just about anywhere. Minors do not care about health hazzards.
I could see it being more appealing, but I feel like most kids would still recognize it as being bad like a cigarette
It might be more appealing as they're the next big thing, but I still don't totally believe that anyone (minors or otherwise) would be convinced that they're safer.
Do you think you will EVER be ready to quit smoking? Why? Why not? #TDII
Yes, of course. Why? When I want to I will. Simple.
Hi 10349 - very cool. How important is quitting to you at the moment from 1 (not at all important) to 10 (very important)?
Anything is possible. But I don't know when or why.
Hi 10336 - sounds like quitting is not at all a priority for you right now or something you even consider. What would make quitting more important for you?
Johannes mmmm id say currently like... A 3.
Ok 10349 - why is it a 3 and not a 1 for example?

Cause it's crossed my mind lately. Mainly with being around my niece... I want to be around a long time to see her grow up. But the at the same time on the other side of her family and mine for that fact- some of the oldest people in my family (78+) oh and those would be aunts and uncles... Have smoked their whole life.... Soooooo... #doessmokingREALLYkill?

10349 - no one can tell you if you'll be among those 50% smokers that die prematurely because of their smoking or not. It's of course your personal choice as everything in life. All we know for sure is that smokers are taking a big risk. Let me repost this article that explains it some more - at least for lung cancer. What do you think about that? http://www.utsouthwestern.edu/life-at/med-talks/why-do-smokers-never-get-lung-cancer.html
I'm not so very sure but I know it won't happen.
Yes. When i have children
No way, Jose! 'When a man thinks, there is a fire alive in his mind-- and it is proper that he should have the point of a cigarette as his one expression.'Ayn Rand says everything so articulately.
46. Have you heard any conflicting information about smokeless tobacco? How do you feel now knowing the truth? #beingconscious
I'm sure I have but I ignored it. My opinion has not changed.

Honestly I can't think I've EVER heard it's "safer" or "less harmful" quite the opposite is pounded into every message out there- almost to an aggressive point. Like... Whoa! Calm your tits, it's okay! We get it. And any person with a normal functioning brain should be able to discern that it's the same thing in a different form.
What 10349 said.
I have not because ive learned the places to educate myself and places to ignore
I've always heard it's just as bad
I've never been told that smokeless tobacco is safer. It was always stressed to me that it's just as bad or even worse.
I  have heard that it is worse for you

45. Another part of the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act (signed into law by President Obama in '09) prevents tobacco companies from making health claims about any supposed “reduced risk” of any of their products that might encourage new smokers or discourage smokers from quitting. Do you think this is fair? #socialreflection
Honestly, I don't really care either way.
I mean if they work hard enough go for it.

I think that's completely fair. Its bad business to make false advertisements. I like to think that the public is smart enough to understand that smoking anything is bad for your health; since that isn't the actual case, I fully support the legislation that markets cigarettes for what they really are instead of sugar coating things. I completely agree with calling "light" or "natural" cigarettes a different name in order to squash the misconceptions.
Its bad to encourage someone to use your product claiming its less harmful when in all reality you get the same result. So yes. Its fair
I also second that last part ^ because stating its light isnt saying how harmful it is. Its information on the product.
I don't think it has any effect on smokers because if you're going to some your going to smoke
I absolutely 100% with 10353! Very well said! Literally took the words from my fingers!
If there actually is reduced risk that seems pretty crappy, but in the more likely case that it's just preventing false advertising that's great

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Not Ready to Quit Yet 7.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: 44. What’s your take on Big Tobacco? Do you defend tobacco companies, or do you side with those who are critical of Big Tobacco? What types of things have you heard about tobacco companies? #beingconscious
Honestly I don't really care, I have absolutely no strong opinions
I guess you could say i support them. They are making money on a product someone created. Like everyone else. Sure theres a lot of bad things about their product but its a persons choice.
They're just like any other big company.
I'm all for them. I know people live to criticize them, but they're marketing a product that has incredibly high profits. When I buy stock, I fully intend to invest in the Altria Group.
Don't much care for them.
I've heard they make lots of money but that's about it

My take? Like a lot of other said- they are like any other huge corporation. They're out to make money. Do I support them? Well... I smoke so... I am part of their profit so... I suppose I support them... Like many thing I do- even though I may not agree with all their decisions or tactics.

43. There are lots of Nicotine Replacement Therapies, or NRT’s, available over-the-counter: the patch, gum, lozenge, nasal spray, and inhaler. What have you heard about NRT’s? Would you ever consider trying them? #beingconscious
I've heard auite a bit about them. The place I work sells a few but I don't plan on using them.
I haven't really heard much about them, and I don't think I'd use them.
If course I've heard about them. I've thought about trying them, but since they still deliver nicotine to your body, I ultimately decided that they're not a great idea.

I've heard they are the woooorrrrssstttt and can make you sick... Obviously if used not as directed... But I don't think I would ever use these... Too scary. I would prefer some sort of homeopathic way - ie. Cold turkey, or even hypnotism.
Maybe, if I decide to quit.
I have and I'd rather try to stop cold turkey

41. A Dartmouth Medical study reported that adolescents who viewed smoking in movies were more than 50% more likely to smoke than those who didn’t watch smoking in movies. What do you think the younger generation is learning about tobacco and cigarettes? #beingconscious
They're learning that it exists. Simple as that.

I wanna know where they get these numbers. I agree with the first comment. Curious because theyve never encountered it before. If everyone was more open about cigarettes then i feel less children are likely to smoke. Like i said before, educate not eliminate
They can see that people smoke. But really, the only people who tend to smoke in movies are bad guys and foreigners.

They're learning of it but that really means nothing. I was taught  about and I've seen many things I don't do. Like crack and meth. Just because you see or hear about something doesn't necessarily mean anything at all.
I think they aren't learning anything from movies
I doubt much. Also, how was this study conducted? Smoking appears in a lot of movies, how can you be sure that a child has never seen it?

42. What do you think middle school and high school nonsmokers are more likely to pick up: a cigarette, which they know are bad, smelly, and frowned upon, or a shiny, gadget-y, trend setting e-cig? Read this article to find out more about how under-aged kids are responding to the new e-cigs craze. #ecig

Honestly, probably cigarettes. Cigarette smoking often comes from having parents or other influential people in one's life who smoke, and I think that those sorts are generally ones who have tried to quit using e cigs, but weren't able to and thus stick to cigarettes. Of course it all boils down to a case by case basis regardless.
An ecigg most definitely!

Hmm... Interesting question... For some rebellious rich bitch kids I think the next newest shiniest gadget. For those other kids who like 10374 said come from smoking households cigarettes for sure. I also then think both groups would at some point go back and forth between the two- and finally pick one or the other, or none at all.
both probably

I would think they'd still prefer paper cigarettes. I doubt that underage kids would have the funds to buy the set ups for the ecigs and the juices to refill them with, and they certainly wouldn't want to keep up with the maintenance. In addition to that, if you aren't supposed to be smoking, it's a lot harder to hide those bulky vaporizers than it is to stash paper cigarettes.
Probably a cigarette, they are cheaper. Plus most kids start smoking because of peer pressure.
When I was middle/highschool age I didn't see cigarettes as "bad and smelly" at all, so I'd say regular cigarettes because they're cheaper and easier to get a hold of.
Have you ever noticed a connection between smoking and your mood? Is there an emotional state that gets you to light up more frequently? #TDII
Of course, every time I'm anything but happy it is the first thing I do.
Thanks for sharing 10336, sounds like your trigger are negative emotions. What else can you do to get yourself out of a bad mood?
Probably just about anything, my dad says just quit thinking about it.
So taking your mind off the bad mood may help. What could you do for distraction?
It depends on what is bothering me. Sometimes going to work solves it just fine.
10336 - if you are interested I can give you some suggestions for pleasant activities that may help to improve your mood. What do you think?
Go for it.
How about these - anything you find useful?

No... Not really. I don't smoke based on feelings... As I try to avoid those all together anyway. Mine more based off connivence. Like... If I wanna have a lazy day off and do nothing, cigarettes don't even cross my mind. Or if I do catch the feels- happy- I don't wanna smoke sad- I reeeeally don't wanna smoke angry- I don't wanna smoke other- I don't really want to smoke.
Thanks for sharing 10349! So what are your triggers? Sounds like you don't have a lot of them.
.... Copious amounts of time......and boredom. Although I suppose those are the same thing.
Sorry guys, I've got to run - see you next week!
When im extemely mad i need one. It gets me away from reality for a minute

A few of them. I love listening to music and reading and writing letters to my friends and family that are far away. I tend to just get in my car and drive sometimes too and others I'll just clean my car. It all depends on the situation at hand.

38. In 2009, President Obama signed into law the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act. Part of this law bans all cigarettes that contain a characterizing flavor, including all fruit and candy flavors. Do you think it's a good thing to ban candy and fruit-flavored cigarettes? Who do you think this portion of the law is trying to protect? #socialreflection
People are going to smoke regardless of what it tastes like
I absolutely agree with 10347! 100000000% agree! Regardless of what "flavor" of cigarette there is... People will smoke.
Yes and no. People are going to smoke regardless. But the flavors stand out more to children.

It's meant to deter kids from smoking. I personally think that's silly, because as mentioned above, people are still going to smoke. Besides, you can buy products like Tasty Puff that will let you flavor your cigarettes anyway.
That doesn't make much sense to me. I would love to have flavored smokes.
I wouldn't say it's a good or bad thing. I assume it's to deter kids from smoking, but even if you flavor a cigarette it still tastes like cigarette, which kids do not like.
great thread!!

39. FACT:  Just like with any other addiction, quitting can be difficult, and it might be hard to do it alone. Would you be able to get the support you need if you wanted to quit smoking? What would you try? #beingconscious
I think I would. I would probably try nicotine patches, if I had to. I wouldn't take any anti-smoking drugs though. I don't like pharmaceuticals.
If i wanted my boyfriend and i would do it together

If I wanted support I absolutely could get it- however throughout my whole life living independently... I've never yearned for support from others. I don't need it and I don't particularly want it... It makes me feel ashamed when people say they are proud of me... I'm not sure what psychological issue that stems from but... I've never liked it.  If and when I want to quit I will. And it will be a decision I make when I'm ready and I'll do it, I honestly probably won't tell anyone until they offer me a cigarette out of habit seeing I'm not lighting up.
I know I would. If I wanted to quit I just would. You can do whatever you set your mind to.
I know id have the support.I'd probably try the old fashioned way
I could definitely get lots of support. I'd try  to go cold turkey, but if I struggled I'd take a smoking cessation class that they offer at my local hospital.
Definitely, my friends and family
Im glad everyone can acknowledge and find some support :)

40. The carbon monoxide level in your blood drops down as the oxygen level in your blood increases back to normal. Have you ever noticed a difference in your breathing when you’ve been without a cigarette for 12 hours? #beingconscious
Yeah, it sucks.
I can't tell the difference in my breathing, but I can feel the difference in how I handle the smoke when its been more than 12 hours in between cigarettes.
No I can't tell the difference in my breathing but I can feel the difference in the way the cigarette effects me.
I don't notice any difference really
I have not
not that I know of
Uhh... No... Haha not unless I smoke like... 2-3 packs in one night I wake up the next day feeling heavy. But on a regular day to day basis nope.
I pretty much always agree with 10353 lol
10347 that's always a good look! Hahaha.
interesting to think about..thanks for the response everyone!!

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Not Ready to Quit Yet 7.
