data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: 37. Children of smokers are far more likely to start smoking than children of nonsmokers and children of ex-smokers. Were you brought up in a home where smoking was allowed? If so, how do you think this affected your decision to start smoking? If not, where do you think your attitudes about smoking originated? #beingconscious

I was brought up in a house where smoking was allowed, everyone in my family old enough to smoke did and most still do. I believe it did affect my decision to start smoking by being a known way of consuming time or relieving anxiety or whatever else in my family.

I was brought up in a family of nonsmokers. The actions of others really have no influence on what each individual is going to do. People are supposed to make decisions for themselves, and nothing someone else says or does is going to change that.
I was brought up in a smoking household but it didn't affect my smoking stress from work did
My mom smoked, but always went to great lengths to avoid exposing me or my siblings to second hand smoke. I think that because of that, I avoid exposing others to second hand smoke now.
Yes. I believe i do because it gives me a sense of comfort
I was raised by my mom, and she's never touched a cigarette in her life. However my aunt smoked, and I did spend a good amount of time with her
Neither of my parents are smokers. Almost no one in my family is a smoker.

36. Social situations can make it hard not to smoke, especially when alcohol is involved. Does alcohol affect your smoking? How would you change that if you wanted to cut down or quit? #beingconscious
I'd simply avoid the situation
No, because I'm already a religious smoker. But if it did affect my smoking and I actually wanted to quit I would just avoid it.
Oh gosh yes, I smoke way more when I drink. I'd probably switch to a vaporizer/e cig to keep around when I drink if I decided to quit smoking paper cigarettes.
I'm not 21 yet.

Ohhhhh laaawwwdddd I can easily smoke 2+ packs in one night if I'm heavily drinking hahaha how could I stop? Uhh... Just.... not I guess?  Haha it would be really hard though... Especially in an inebriated state? That's a toughy!!
I feel it makes me smoke less. Personally. But on average i believe it makes people smoke more.
I'm also not 21
Oh my goodness!!! 10374 and 10358 not 21 giiiiiiiiiiiiiirls. Come see me when you turn of age. I'll show you a semi smokeless good time :D
30. Cats are exposed to secondhand smoke toxins through breathing in the smoke around them, AND when they groom themselves. How can we help Fifi stop smoking? #smokingaffectsall

This really got to me because I have 3 cats, all of whom I love dearly. I always smoke outside, and they are strictly indoor kitties. I hope that that cuts down on their exposure. I'll also make sure that I stay away from the windows while  I smoke next time I have them open.
Don't smoke around your pets
Restrict the animal from where you ususlly smoke.
smoke away from animals
The questions presented by this page are getting more and more 2 dimensional and propaganda oriented, and less and less answerable for me.
I hate cats.  Fuck them. Not saying I'll intentionally hurt them by any means. But the less cats the better.
Never smoke around pets

10374 interesting point! thank you for being honest and sharing, although what do you mean propaganda oriented? This question is intended to make you think about the other living organisms- humans, animals, etc. that are affected, and more or less, unintentionally harmed by your smoking habits. Before creating this post, I had no idea cats were affected by the toxins made by smoke! So, I hope this post at least created awareness, and everyone learned something knew about the affect their smoking habits may have on others!

Awareness perhaps, but it feels like you're using something many people care about as a guilt tactic, rather than providing hard studies and facts with actual, engaging questions which have substance.

thank you for sharing 10374 we try to not make people feel guilty for their habit, just, as I said before, more awareness and focusing on the impacts smoking has on your body and others. Of course quitting is the goal of these groups but we certainly aren't trying to guilt anyone into doing anything. Every post and link we provide are accurate and reliable statistics and information.

34. If you quit smoking, the amount of secondhand smoke present in your home will decrease immediately, keeping your pets safe. Post a pic of your pet if you have one. How much did you think about nearby animals when you lit up before? #smokingaffectsall
I don't have an animal. So I don't think about it.

More guilt tactics huh? I'll indulge. I offer animals the exact same amount of respect I offer humans. I attempt to avoid exposing them to second hand smoke, but I don't force them away in doing so. The only real difference is that if an animal insists on being present while I'm smoking, I stop smoking, as they are generally perceived as being incapable of understanding the hazards.
Again, I don't smoke inside, so I really don't think they are exposed to much second-hand smoke save what they can smell on my hands and clothes. I think they would love me regardless.
my animals aren't exposed to smoke so I don't worry about it
Well wait.... 1- I don't smoke inside... I wasn't raised in the 70's. 2- my dog is the most important person in my life... I would never put her in harms way.
I can't currently take a picture but they aren't around me when i smoke so i don't think about it
I don't have a pet in my house, and don't smoke inside
seems like a lot of people have animals! thanks for sharing pictures and honest posts!
35. Tell us how you get rid of the smoky smell after a cigarette. #balance
no I don't but I've never really had any one complain about it
I always ensure that I am upwind of my smoke, and I wash my hands. Doesn't take any more than that for me.
I don't bother. I can't smell it on myself, so I always assume that nobody else can either
I don't..

Handi wipes and breath spray :-) ooooooor cologne... I don't know I've never had anyone tell me I smell like smoke, I've known people for lengthy amounts of time and never know I smoke cause I never smell like it- it's never been a problem for me, also cause I'm very hygienic haha
I don't. I've actually had people comment on how little I smell of smoke for a smoker.
Body spray
Have you ever tried to quit or reduce your smoking? Which strategy did you choose and how did it go? #TDII
No I have not.
Hi 10336 - if you were ever ready to try it in the future, how would you go about it?
I'm not quite sure. My dad quit about three years ago. Just because he felt like it.
And how did he do it? Do you know which strategy he chose and what his reasons were for quitting?
He just quit. There was no strategy nor reasoning. He just decided he was never going to smoke again one Friday morning.
I've done that. I got bored of smoking, so I stopped for a few months. I've done that a few times. I picked it up again because I tend to smoke whenever I'm bored.
That's very interesting 10336 - and how does your Dad feel about your smoking? Did he ever give you any recommendations?
Hi 10374 - thanks for sharing! When you stopped smoking in the past was it hard for you at all? Did you ever have any urges or withdrawal symptoms?
He would like to shove the pack down my throat sometimes.. But he isn't hypocritical about it, when he was my age he was a smoker too. Recommendations? No. Lectures. Yes.
Naturally, but nothing I was unable to handle. My issue isn't quitting being difficult, it's that I don't want to.
10336 what do you think about this lectures? Do you think he has a point?
10374 is there anything that would be a strong motivator for you? Do you think you will ever be ready to quit in the future?
I think it annoying as hell.
Haha fair enough 10336 - what does he say?
He might have a point but nonetheless they lean toward hypocritical. And he refuses to be looked at as a hypocrite, so he just says slick little things.
Ok, I understand 10336 - is there anything he could say on this topic that wouldn't be as annoying? What could he do to be more helpful?

"I remember when I smoked cigarettes and smelt like a dirty ashtray." My favorite is "Thats how papa died, you know?" Obviously I know how my grandfather died but at the same time my grandmother is still smoking. My dad smoked for thirty something years.
No probably not. Its one of those things people just have to figure out on their own.
You are probably right there 10336 - what would have to happen to get you more motivated about quitting?
Yes! I quit. I did really well! 3 months no cigarettes. Then I got a promotion and was in ultimately high stress position aaaand started smoking again.
Hi 10349 - stress is definitely a big time trigger. How could you try to approach stressful situations without a cig? Have you ever tried alternative approaches and how did they work?

Something would have to happen to me personally. I do believe thst each person responds differently and until there is a difference that affects me directly I'm not even going to think about quitting. Yeah it sucks watching people die from smoking but it doesn't mean I'm going to tell them how to live their life. It is theirs, not mine.
10336 - I agree, we each have to make our own decisions and no one can make them for us. How would you tell someone else if you were concerned about something they did?
I'm pretty blunt. If I have something to say about you I am going to make my opinion known and not care at all. But its just an opinion.
10336 is your dad like that too if he lectures you on your smoking?
33. Being labeled as “the smoker” can be tough. Have you ever felt uncomfortable around people who don’t smoke? #balance
A little, sometimes.
No.
Sometimes
no I have not but I don't care what others think about me
Mm... Not really...? If they don't like it that's fine and I respect that but they should also respect me and the fact I smoke.
No, I've never been uncomfortable because of it. To each his own. Besides, it's not like I force people to be around me while I smoke.
No i haven't because it's a part of me

data.message: 31. Quitting smoking can help preserve our planet! Without cigarette smoke, the chances of household fires decrease and less secondhand smoke is added into the air we breathe. Can you think of any other environmental improvements that might result from less smoke? #beingconscious
I asked my environmental science teacher if smoking made any significant difference to our planet's well being, and he said no. Besides the litter and second-hand smoke, I agree.
Aaaand theyre making biodegradable filters with flower seeds in them. So when people throw their butts theyre planting flowers

I very strongly have to disagree with aaalllll of this. Haha minutes maaaybe the house fires... But that's only if you smoke inside.... I feel like not many people do that anymore.  And if you do its your own damn fault and you're stupid. And on the side of the environment? Really?  your joking right? You think the smoke from CIGARETTES has a significant impact on the environment? Ha haha you're joking right? Compared to the hundreds of thousands of jet, car and coal emissions we pump into the air. Smoking is such a drop in the ocean on this issue.  However I do like 10347's idea... That would be an interesting  work around to have the seeds not be affected by the smoke being pulled through the  filter... Hmmmm....
Except for the smoke and litter I don't see anything bothering the planet.
Yeah no.
I don't think there is any real impact our cigarettes have on the environment
I feel like the only real threat to the environment from smoking is the butts, but even then every smoker I know is pretty good about not just flicking them wherever
Taking a step back and realizing other people, and even the environment, are impacted by our smoking habits is important to do every once and awhile- thanks for sharing everyone!-Kat

29. It’s true, we all know quitting smoking is hard. But switching to another, more socially-acceptable way of ingesting nicotine won’t help you conquer your addiction. What would you rather do, take the easy way and switch to e-cigs, staying addicted and making these e-cig companies more money, or quit once and for all to live free of any level of nicotine-addiction? How would you “enjoy your life more”? #ecig
I don't plan on doing either. I expect to be a smoker for a long time. If I do ever quit,  I'll probably try to go cold turkey.
Neither one interests me but if I had to choose I would choose to just quit. I will never smoke an e-ciagrette. They can give you pneumonia. I'll pass on that.
Oh lawd!!! Quit all together! Obvi!!

Up until this point this page seemed fairly reasonable, but this post is particularly radical in it's anti-smoking propaganda. There's no facts, no actual question to prompt thought, it's just guilt tactics.
Not going to buy an ecig. But not quitting for a while either
I don't really know probably just switch
I suppose quit once and for all

25. LADIES: Quitting smoking can reduce your risk of breast and cervical cancer. Does this seem like a good reason to think about quitting? Guys, does this seem like a reason to encourage female loved ones to quit? #beingconscious
Its a logical reason.
Common sense would tell you that's a good reason to quit
I smoke so I'm not gunna try and convince anyone to quit..
But 'smoking sense' is like 'nahhhhh that won't happen to me. I'm good.'Lol

Because I have too many people in my life affected by breast cancer- and it hits close to home a lot, I always encourage my female friends(which is all of them) to get their annual mammograms- as far as quitting smoking. People will quit when they are ready, and if they don't- well we all die in the end. Smokers and non smokers.  Morbid, I know but. #sorryboutit
^^ Exactly.
It makes sense, but if I was concerned about getting cancer, I wouldn't have started smoking in the first place.
Not as much as lung cancer scares me. There are other ways to have children
I know that's not all those prevent butttt yea
I'd be more worried about lung cancer being a problem
thank you for the honesty! good thread
I wouldn't force someone to stop
28.For which reasons would your children, real or imagined, thank you most for quitting smoking? #smokingaffectsall
I don't know, and frankly don't care. I'm more or less neutral on the topic of having kids, and hypotheticals are pointless.
I would never have kids. If I did, they would surely turn out just like me, and they'd probably grow up to be smokers too.
so there daddy could stay around for a long time
So that I'll be able to play with them for a long time- until they are too old to play anymore, then again to be able to play with my grandchildren until they are too old to play anymore.
Because they don't want me to get sick.
They won't have to. I know I'll have to stop some day and when i have kids is when ill do it
So I could play with them more with out getting tired

27. Due to the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act, tobacco companies have been banned from outdoor advertising within 1,000 feet of school and playgrounds. Do you approve this portion of the Act? What do you think? #socialreflection

Hmm.... I personally think initially GREAT!!! But unless all children are raised under rocks, they're going to see it eventually... So really... What's the hope here? That your children will never see big tobacco adverts? Tsk tsk tsk... Idiots. If you truly believe that not advertising near schools or playgrounds will keep your kids from smoking...
Yea.. they don't need to be advertising near young children.. children are impressionable..
I'm okay with that. But it's not like kids don't go anywhere else where they can see the advertisements. Its a step in the right direction, but it doesn't totally solve the problem.
Of course. Smoking shouldn't be around children anyway.

Yes because eventhough i smoke i dont want kids to smoke. Advertisments about smoking around a childrens area is wrong. Advertisements should be put where the people who need to see them do, not where its convenient. Especially for products that have a minimum age requirement
Yeah that all seems more than reasonable
I agree with that it helps kids alot
It's the consumer's responsibilitu to understand the weight of their purchases, not anybody else's to try and make them know it. A futile effort, ultimately.
What is currently your biggest smoking trigger? #TDII
Stress.
It's a toss up between stress and riding in a car. Stress is obvious; but whenever I get in a car I feel like I have to smoke, even if I'm only driving for like 2 minutes.
Hi 10336, so smoking helps you to deal with stress and calms you down. What kind of situations usually cause this stress?
Nine times out of ten its because I have to bite my tongue when I don't want to.

Hi 10353, so stress for you as well and your car - that's also a very common one. Have any of you guys ever experimented with things you can do to reduce the stress without actually smoking a cigarette?
Smoke pot or drink a beer. Neither are viable options. Haha. Sometimes I hang out with my pets or just chill in a dark quiet room for a few minutes. Those both help a little.
Yeah, pot or a drink don't sound like the right strategies while driving. Have any of you guys ever tried deep breathing exercises for stress reduction? 10336 10353
I have maybe a total of 3 times. Maybe I was doing something wrong, but they didn't do much for me.
No.
Ok 10353 10336 - if you are interested try this and focus on your breath. Does this sound like it could work for you?
Yeah, that sounds like it might work. I might give it a shot sometime.
I'll attempt but I doubt it. I like smoking.

10336 - sure give it a try. Experiments can be helpful because they can sometimes help us to realize we could get through a trigger without smoking when we didn't think we could. I urge everyone to try some type of experiment this week if you can.
Boredom.
26. Who in your life nags you about smoking? What are their reasons for feeling the way that they do? #smokingaffectsall
No one actualy.. most everyone I know smokes also
My mom....She's doesn't want me to get sick
Honestly. No one nags me. I dont have anyone in my life who would be in the position to
No one really
I wouldn't go as far as nagging but my mom always asks if I still smoke- obviously she's just concerned about the health risks.
My wife to be and my grandma. They want me around for a while
Potential romantic prospects, they think it's gross
My mom. She's worried about my health. She's always been adamant about not smoking.

data.message: 24. Male-smokers: Quitting could reduce your risk for erectile dysfunction. What do you think about that? Ladies: would this fact inspire you to encourage your male loved ones to quit? #beingconscious
Not really. It isn't my job to tell others what to do. I might say something about it. But I'm not going to be a hypocrite.
I think it would be best in that case
I entirely agree with what 10336 said
Nah, I'd be more likely to encourage a vegan diet, which also counters ED. But to each his own, I can always take care of myself.
I know the risks of smoking, as it's my responsibility as a consumer to understand what I'm purchasing. I've chosen to accept these risks, and any consequences from them. There's not much else to it.
What do I think about it? I think that's a very interesting factoid. That's all. While sex is a very important part of a relationship it's not everything.
I agree with the first comment 100% ill make sure theyre aware but not be a hypoctite and ask them to quit
wow great thread everyone! thank you for sharing
I'll deal with that bridge when I come to it
19.Can you relate to your best smoking buddy on anything other than smoking? #smokingaffectsall
Um, yeah! That would be my brother, so we have almost everything we can relate to with each other. How silly!
Don't really have one.

Of couuuuurrrssse! What an idiotic question. My best smoking buddy is my best friend. All of them are! Honestly smoking has made me a much more social person, I'm naturally a quiet awkward introverted person, smoking has helped me cracked my shell open. So, no.
I can definitely relate to that.
Definitely
Everything! My buddy is my fiance
I don't really have smoking buddies
most of all of my friends smoke,, so yes
thanks for sharing everyone!
22. Do you have a family member or know someone who has been diagnosed with some form of cancer? How has their life changed?
My mom. 4th stage small cell lung cancer that spread to her brain and all her other organs.. She passes when i was 16
A family friend was diagnosed with cancer (I don't know what kind specifically). She passed away a few months ago.
My grandfather got lung cancer and throat cancer. He lived for quite a while with only one lung and still smoked. The throat cancer took him.
Yes, but I don't know them very well.
I did she was my cousin Celeste she died earlier this month we had her funeral this past tuesday
None of my family smokes. But my highschool best friend's grandmother died of lung cancer
my grandmother has breastcancer but it hasnt affected her life too terribly
My mothers mother was diagnosed with skin cancer.  She passed away, I have no memories of her.
My step-grandmother, but she got better reallly fast so it didn't affect her much at all
thank you for sharing everyone. this is definitely a hard topic and i appreciate the openness :)
What do you guys like about smoking? #TDII
The smoke is pretty.
Also, it's almost a watered down sort of necrophilia, each drag a kiss with death, approaching the veil without crossing. Like an adrenaline junkies death-defying rush, but much slower, more sensual.
Thanks for sharing 10374, so you like the sensual aspects, how it feels and how it makes you feel/what you associate with it, if I get that correctly? Are there any aspects you don't like about it?
I don't. Smoking is a nasty terrible habit that gives you bad breath and smelly hands. Like I said on a post a while ago- it's a habitual thing now.
Hi 10349, for you smoking has become a habit and there is nothing else you like about it anymore, right? Was that different at some point? What did you like about it when you first started smoking?
I don't really know. I just enjoy it.
Yes and no. The parts I don't like about it, I do like. It's complicated and sensual and abstract.
Hi 10336, do you enjoy the feeling of relaxation or the social aspects, or something different altogether?
10374 that sounds really interesting and a little complicated :). Maybe you can help me understand.
Probably all of the above.

It's sort of based on the idea of pain reminding us we're alive. So when I cough, or imagine I can feel the toxins in my skin, it helps to remind me that I can die, which gives me a morbid sort of comfort. I'm not very good at staying "grounded" so to speak, and that sort of thinking helps me to stay in touch with what's around me.
But mostly the smoke is pretty.
10336, so smoking has many positive aspects for you like relaxation, socializing etc. Are there any things about smoking you don't like so much?
The nicotine that feeds my addiction

10374 smoking helps you to stay grounded and in touch with your body and surroundings, sounds like. But then you also said that the same aspects you like you also don't like about it, if I got that correctly. What do you mean by that?
The coughing, the taste, the knowledge of the toxins. They're what I don't like, but they're also what ground me.
Hi 10315, thanks for sharing. So you smoke to get the nicotine because you are addicted to it. Is there anything else you like about smoking, any other positive aspects?
Helps pass the time.
I don't like it in my eyes.
10374 I'm wondering if there are other things that give you the feeling of being grounded that don't have all the negative aspects that you don't like?
10315, smoking feeds your nicotine addiction and helps you pass the time, on the plus side. Are there any negative aspects to smoking for you?
10336 you don't like when the smoke get's into your eyes. Anything else you don't like about smoking?
Smoking inside is gross.
Meditation, at times, but I find I often lack the time and patience. I'm sure there's other things I can't think of at the moment.
Smoking inside is quite gross.
23. Your blood rate decreases, your pulse rate drops, and the temperature of your hands and feet increases. Have you ever noticed these changes after smoking? #beingconscious
i havent,, but il check next time
No.
I actually normally feel like my pulse increases... And my hands and feet get Coker a wee bit. But of the above things-- nope.
I can kind of tell with my pulse rate, especially if I'm really stressed and I go have a smoke. The other two not so much.
Sorta, with my pulse
I have not
No I don't

21. FACT: Nicotine is a very addictive drug. For some, it can be as addictive as heroin or cocaine. Have you ever had someone belittle the power of your addiction? What was it like? What did they say? #beingconscious
Never. Do people actually do that?
I have no one who cares whether i smoke or not so no
My dad. He just says that I'm killing myself slowly.
Never. Addiction is addiction, it doesn't matter what your chosen poison is.
Nope. Can't say I have. People just kinda accept it and move on.
I've never really had that problem
Same. My parents think I just don't try hard enough
i dont think ive ever had that discussion with someone
Not really
17.Is there someone in your life that you'd be proud to tell that you quit smoking? What do you think they would say? #smokingaffectsall
My little sister
My dad. He would be overly excited and tell me the story of how he quit again.
No one looks up to me and i dont have anyone to look up to. So no.
My mom and siblings.
My mama. She always was adamant that my brother and I not smoke, and she's the only one who makes a point about us quitting. She would be very proud of us if either would quit ASAP.
My parents, and my friends would probably be pretty proud too.
Whew! Back from camping! Uhh... No. Just. No, no one really cares...
My mom and fiance would be thrilled
my parents probably
16.Would your life be different if others’ first impression of you was not smoky? #balance
Its possible. I wouldn't know for sure though.

If people have ever been prejudiced against me because I smoke, they've always been too polite to say so. I don't think it makes much of a difference, as long as the smoker isn't rude about their habit.
I go to lengths to ensure that I'm not smoky.
I doubt it. It isnt one of my main qualities
I don't think so, I make an effort to not smell like smoke and never really first meet people when I am currently smoking, unless they are also smokers
No. I never tell people I smoke when I first meet them. Unless they ask. I don't want people judging me for smoking.
I don't believe so
doubt it

Does the doctor posts count?

Kinda. From my dad. He knows I smoke but I don't like smoking in front of him. It doesn't bother me any, mostly considering it is my choice.
Kinda the same. My parents know but I won't do it in front of them
I don't have to hide it. Ever
Not in the slightest.
I don't hide it per say, but I don't do it around my parents just out of sheer respect. How does it affect me? .... It doesn't...? Haha
I don't hide it anymore. Haven't bothered since I was old enough to buy my own smokes.
Not really
I'm pretty sure my parents know but I still make it an effort to hide it from them
No i don't
nope

20. Big Tobacco is advertising E-Cigarettes as a safer and better way to smoke, but studies have shown that they still contain toxins, even without the smoke. Why do you think so many people who smoke are ready to adopt new products even before proper research on their safety has happened? #beingconscious
Because they can have it inside.
Because people realize smoking is bad,but don't want to quit, so they're eager to believe anything that seems better
They want it to be better?
They believe what they are told on tv

Haha... Do you honestly expect people to research what the hell they put into their bodies? People always look for a "quick fix" and don't want to take the time or effort to actually find out what is really happening or take the time to fix/resolve something. Why do you think we are so complacent with products that is in our food now-a-days? We are fed this propaganda bullshit from the media telling us its "healthy" or  "see results 3 times as fast!" We are lazy. Like... Hella lazy.
People believe what they're told. But I do know some people who have just used them to transition to completely quit smoking.
Good advertising
ppl jus looking for a new fad

Hello TSP members! We're still waiting for me people to join us before we launch! We want you to know that this secret group is a great place to share your thoughts and engage in conversation. Please feel free to like or respond to each others' comments and share any relevant content of your own.To begin, let's take a moment to introduce ourselves and get to know each other a little better. Feel free to share with us:• Where you come from• Anything about your smoking (how much, how often, when you first started, etc.)• What you hope to gain from participating in the Tobacco Study ProjectThank you! We hope you're as excited as we are!
Please feel free to share! We'd love to know a little bit more about you :)

A belated hello to all. I'm 10353, but you can call me Casanova if you'd like. I really enjoy smoking, as well as hiking, camping, (recently) kayaking, as well as some other things. I'm looking forward to participating in this study in the name of science and research. Good luck to all participants!
I'm 10347. I started smoking when i was 17. I've been with my boyfriend for 4 years and he smokes too. I'm from PA
14. How could you have a more active lifestyle without smoking? #balance
could actually skateboard without feeling like I was gun die every 5 minutes,,lol
Running would be easier without coughing.
Ive never not done something from being out of breath, but i may be able to afford to do more things
I used to be really into running and learned how to deal with being out of breath, but it would still be nice to go up 2+ flights of stairs without having to pause and catch my breath after

I could swim again. Without DYING. I swam 11 years competitively. And on a non "active" side I could play my instrument again. God I would die to have the lung capacity I did in high school simply to create music again, it was really heart breaking picking up my instrument after a few years smoking and not be able to sustain or play as well...

The types of activities I usually do (hiking and kayaking) aren't really affected. I guess I would be able to swim a little better, and running would probably be easier. Swimming is the major one, because I can definitely feel a diminished lung capacity when I get in the water.
I've never had any issues with being short of breath. Though I might quit for theater, to save my singing voice.
thanks for sharing!!
I am already active because of my job and it doesn't affect me

data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: Did you know that you can avoid almost all of the negative long-term health consequences of smoking if you quit before you are 30 years old? Does that change how you feel about smoking and quitting? #TDII
Tempts me to just quit at the last second.
No.. My grandmother is eighty five years old. And smoked a cigarette with me today.

Haha fair enough 10374 - I should also say that these average data obviously don't necessarily hold true for each individual, so if you want to be safe you probably shouldn't wait until the very last second. If you ever wanted to quit, how confident are you that you could do it?
If I wanted to, I doubt it would be very hard. Thing is, all the usual reasons (health, money, etc) aren't very strong motivators for me.
Hi 10336, I'm glad to hear your grandmother is doing fine at 85 despite her smoking. Do you also know anyone who has been negatively affected from smoking?
10374, so you are not concerned about your health or loosing money or giving it to big tobacco at all?

My grandfather, her husband, passed away in 1998 of throat cancer. Which was after the lung cancer. He survived for many years with one lung and a very avid smoker until he got throat cancer. I have a highly stubborn family.

My health and losing money, not in the slightest. I'll live in whatever way suits me in the moment, and I'm excited to see the culmination of all my desicions, good and bad, when I die. I don't put much value into material objects, nor the money that buys them. Giving it to big tobacco is more of a grey area. Big companies bother me regardless, and there's a whole host of other ones I'm forced to feed into out of convenience.
10336 - so you are also too stubborn to think about quitting?
I am stubborn. Very stubborn.
I'm not stubborn. I just haven't been presented with a reason for quitting that actually means much to me.

10374, how you live your life is of course your decision and no one can force you to quit if you don't want to. Maybe you will find the resources we share here at TSP useful anyways or you will be able to use them some day should you ever change your mind. Let me know if you have any questions about any of this.

I mean, I have and at the dame time haven't. My grandpa died because of cancer caused by smoking but my grandmother is eighty five and still smokes like a freight train. It affects people differently so I'm not going to base my decisions off one bad incident.

I am curious as to why a research project seems so biased against smoking. Just seems odd to me for something so scientific as a research project to push so strongly for one side of the subject matter.
I don't mean to be attacking our offensive, of course. Just curious to me.

10336, I agree that it's not a good strategy to base your decisions on single examples. However, what we know from studies with thousands of people is that on average a smoker looses 10 years of their life. Check out this study if you're interested to learn more http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1211128 What do you think about this?

That's a great question 10374. In general we know that smoking causes great harm to individuals and the society at large, so we conduct studies to find out how to best help people change their smoking behavior if they want to. What do you think about that?
Where's the proof doc? Let me see the studies

I feel like it's a little bit too much of a good cause, honestly. As long as the 'if they want to' qualifier is retained I don't see the harm, but at the same time, I feel that harm is perspective. If there were such thing as someone who truly lived a happier, more fulfilling, (though likely shorter) life because of smoking, is it still harm to the individual?
This is one study 10349 http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1211128 but there are plenty more if you're interested. What do you think about that?

Isn't it true that smoking has never been directly linked to CAUSING these deaths? Simply being a factor? No offense but until someone shows me a step by step study done that shows smoking caused someone's death- I won't be convinced.

10349, there is absolutely no doubt that smoking causes these deaths, and even internal tobacco industry documents reveal that they have know this for decades. I can find more studies if you're interested.

I think it's highly presumptuous to outright say smoking causes these deaths. Not to say it does not aid in quickening the process, although that's debatable as well- however smoking does not and did not cause any of these people to die in the study you presented to me.  Death is an inevitable part of life- am I wrong doc? You saying smoking CAUSED the deaths of the participants in the study, says in latent terms, if these participants didn't or would not have smoked they would not die.

Well of course we are talking about risk and not every person is the same. Two people could smoke exactly the same number of cigs in their life and one person may die from it and the other still lives. So yes, in this kind of study design we can't say anything more than that. A study to prove that smoking causes death in humans would be an experiment where you have identical twins in the exact same environment, give cigs to one person and no cigs to the other and see what happens. Such a study is obviously not ethical so we can't do it. However, from animal studies and studies on cells we know that constituents of tobacco smoke CAUSE cancer. And the data we have from studies with humans absolutely support this hypothesis. There simply is no other reasonable explanation for so many deaths in smokers. Of course what you believe is up to you. I'm just trying to give you the most comprehensive information.
I've got to run guys. Great discussion today :) see you next week!

15.Most people who smoke report dealing with stress as their top reason for smoking. Work, class, family, friends, significant others -- it can be a lot! Can you think of another way to deal with stress that doesn’t involve lighting up when things get tough? What could you do instead? #balance
Exercise.
Exercise. Art
play with ur pet, exercise, music,
Taking a walk, hot showers/baths, art

Go climb a mountain! Or I guess exercise in general (but climbing mountains is better). Or going away from people and screaming for ten whole minutes. Haha. I'm not that great at stress relief  without a crutch.
I don't smoke due to stress. I have made the conscious decision to not have stress in my life so this is hard to answer... But working out always helps make me feel better:-)
Meditation.
Scribble furiously
Just drink a good cup if coffee and listen to music
13. Post your wish list here! #balance
I'd pay off my court fines and get my licence,,lol
New wardrobe. Car repairs.
I wish to move to Granbury, Texas.
Nothing worth having.
Maybe new clothes, but quitting wouldn't really save me all that much money
I actually get my cigarettes for free now. But I probably would have bought a few pairs of jeans and saved the money that I had spent on cigarettes prior to gaining this privilege.
Food. And heels!!!  yaassss!!! I need some new pumps!
Not sure probably fix my car

12. Yesterday we asked you to tell us how confident you were that you COULD quit smoking if you wanted to. What would it take to get you from the number you said yesterday to ONE NUMBER HIGHER? #motivation
A personal experience.
idk some sort of cancer probably
Just one number higher? A change in mindset. Easily said, not easily done.
Hmm..... Like I said yesterday. A want to. It's not a matter of will- got lots of that. Just something to push me toward quitting for good.
Ps- are we supposed to share this too? I thought this was "secret" or whatever?
Wanting to quit.
If I wanted to quit
I guess wanting to quit or just a traumatic experience
Knowing i wouldn't be stressed
thank you for everyone's honesty in sharing!
11. We understand that stopping smoking is not easy. On a scale of 1-10, how confident are you that you COULD quit smoking if you tried? #motivation
Ehhhhhhhhhh 5
mayyyybe 4-5?
i feel like a 6 or 7
1. I've tried to quit a few times before, and was never successful, so I feel like it would be the same if I tried again.
Like a 3
Oh on a 1-10 assuming 10 is successful?...... Still a 100. Addictions are not hard for me to break, I've never had an addictive personality, it would just be a matter of, not even will just want.

data.message: 5. What would be the best-case scenario if you quit smoking? #motivation
10347 it's here! You eager little beaver you!

Best case scenario? That's fairly vague... But I suppose I'd never pick up/and or have the urge to ever smoke again. Get healthier, and just live a better more productive life, not having to worry about when my next cigarette break is.
My teeth would look better and i would have more money
I would feel better and perhaps take care of myself more
I wouldn't want to smoke, and I wouldn't be in a foul mood through the quitting process.
It would cause better lung function and whiter teeth.
definitely save alotta moneyy,,lol
Stay away from people that smoke.
I would save my health and money
thank you for sharing everyone!
10. What is keeping quitting smoking from the top of your priorities list? What would make quitting even more important to you? #motivation
I'm not quite sure. I guess it just kinda keeps me from freaking out. It gives me time to go outside and control my temper before it gets out of control.

I don't want to quit. I genuinely enjoy smoking cigarettes and I see no reason to stop. I don't think anything would move it to the top of my priority list either. If I get health problems from it, the damage would already be done and there still wouldn't be any reason for me to quit. I'm pretty stubborn.
jus doesn't seem important to me atm,, doesn't affect my life right now really,,

It's not a big deal to me. It's just smoking. Ha I say that yet "just smoking" has aided in many cases of lung cancer and other horrific diseases  yet. It's not something I really care about- smoking to me can go either way- take it or leave it.  What would change that? Children. Always children.
It helps me deal with stress and it gives me a sense of comfort
If I couldn't get cigarettes, that would move it up.

I get very easily stressed out and life's been really hard lately, it helps me manage all the stress. The only thing that would make quitting a priority now would be if I got some type of sick from it

I feel that this is a difficult question, because while I can't speak for others, for me quitting is mostly neutral on the spectrum of desire. For some, it's outright undesirable, so asking what would make it more of a priority is like asking someone what would make stubbing their toe or jumping up and down more of a priority. It's already either inconsequential or undesirable, so barring extreme circumstance, not much would make us want it. Again, I only speak for myself though.
I guess just the fact that I'm to stressed out. It helps me relax and get my focus  back
9. On a scale of 1-10, how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #motivation
2. Its really not a priority for me.
maybe a 1
Like a 3 maybe? On a really "motivated" day
Right now 3
8. Do you think you will ever want to quit smoking? If yes, when? #motivation
maybe at some point, when I find the reason to.
*shrug*
When i get pregnant i will stop smoking.
Eventually.....

Do I think I will? Yes. In reality? Probably not. Even if I "quit" at some point for good- in the back of my head I just know that 'last' cigarette will never come. It's become a force of habit now, it's not even that I need it so much as I just feel I should have it.

I smoke because I'm hoping for an early death. I don't want to quit, and in all honesty the only thing that I think would make me quit is being physically barred from smoking (long hospital stay or something similar).
Definitely, as soon as I get done with college.
I don't really know maybe
I would stop throughoutva pregnancy but chances are I'd pick it back up. I have no real desire to quit,

7. How would you react if you found out your son or daughter smoked cigarettes?  #motivation
If under the legal age to, they would be reprimanded. If not, ensure that they are fully and truly aware of everything they're getting into and how much it sucks, then let them make their own choice.
I did when I was younger,, depends how young though,, but it's their own personnel choice to make
I probably wouldn't be too happy. But I'd have to accept it if my child was of age. If my child was not of age I'd try to keep him or her away from cigarettes the best I could.
I don't even wanna think about my son smoking anything.
If they're old enough, I'll be upset, but let them make their own decisions. If they're underage, then I'm not having it.
I would be disappointed but as long as theyre old enough (legal) i would just hope they knew all the consequences

I would just tell them about my experience with smoking, pros and cons, why they really shouldn't do it, etc. If they were underage I certainly wouldn't help them get cigarettes; if they were legal though, I don't think I'd have a problem with it. After all, that would be like the pot calling the kettle black. But alas, I only want fur babies anyway.

I would hope that my child and I have a good enough relationship that I don't "find out" and that they would talk to me about pros/cons and outcomes of smoking before they ever take that first drag- hopefully they'll have the sense to never even do it, but if they do just honesty I suppose.
I would be a little upset if they didn't tell me they started but other then that I'd let them decide for themselves
thank you for all of these responses! this is a great thread :)- kat from tsp
It really depends on the age, if they're an adult I'd tell them that I was disappointed and see if I could convince them to quit. If they're underage they are getting so grounded.
6. What’s the worst thing that could happen if you don’t quit smoking? #motivation
Getting a tracheotomy would be absolutely horrible. Cancer doesn't sound too great either.
I'm assuming some sort of cancer and loss of teeth
I don't want my little sister to ever start, just bc she sees me. (She's 9 right now)
Impaired living/influence on those younger than me.
Having to have someone give up their life to take care of me due to  emphysema... I could never take away someone's life.
Cliche but develop lung cancer down the road like my mom or lose out on all that money i spend on cigarettes
I could develop some sort of cancer and die at a young age
Death.
The obvious cancer and other health problems, also the chance that one day a cigarette won't go out and burn my house down
4. What was your reason for picking up that first cigarette? Was it to be cool, to be independent, to experiment, to look older, or something else? #beingconscious
Experimentation, and a deluded sense of peer pressure, personally.

I started smoking at 15 because of pressure from my brother, and because I started hanging out with older kids who all smoked. I did think it made me cooler (still do!), even though I knew it was bad for me. I didn't even like smoking at first, but I didn't want my cool new friends to think I was a square, so I persisted.
I started because it have me a sense of comfort after my mom passed (she smoked)
Age 16
I needed to relieve stress

This one is hard to answer. I guess after my best friends brother committed suicide, she picked it up- be it the nature of rebellion after a tragedy, or nurture that both her parents smoke. And by sheer time spent with her I picked it up too. I don't blame her by any means, but she did smoke my first, second, third fourth fifth... And so on cigarettes with me. I guess I felt I was helping her by joining in? Odd I know... oh and this was when I was 12. I'm now 22, so 10 years ago.
To stay away from people who smoke.
When, I was 14 and yes because my friends did it
Everyone in my family smoked.
My brother got me started. I was 15, he was 17.
When I was 14 because a lot of my friends smoked and I was curious, not much peer pressure involved.
1. Share a success that you have had in the past. It can be anything from any time. Why did it work? Who helped you? #motivation
I became a manager at my job. I studied hard and my fiance also helped me study. Ive been a manager for almost a year now :)
I graduated after dropping out. My dad bought me a car so I could go to a special school for students just like me.

Similar to 10347, becoming a manager at a young age- being the youngest manager of a swimming complex... It took 7 years of hard work, dedication and lots of sunburns. Lots of trial and error- but with the help of my mentors and small knit group of friends and coworkers, persistence paid off. I was a manager for 2 years before I left that job. From that experience I learned working hard and having a goal- with time, blood sweat and tears you can reach and even supersede your goals. (Cliché I know but - eh)
I graduated high school after dropping out twice

I think my biggest success would have to be deciding to get help with my serious depression rather than ending my own life. Its been an uphill battle, but my boyfriend, friends, and family have offered me support along the way. They keep me going. (:
prolly my parents helping me while I started up school again after dropping out
My second semester of college I got a 3.52 gpa, my first semester I had gotten a 1.74. I studied and worked so hard and had support from my parents.
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions! #TDII
3. How would you support someone who tells you they want to quit smoking? #motivation

How? A- never offer them a smoke. What an asshole move. B- don't smoke around them, not for a while anyway, what an awful temptation for someone trying to kick it.  C-offer any help or support I can for them.
Well I'd offer a helping hand and I would make sure I kept my bad habits as far away from them as I could.
Yep
I wouldnt offer them acigg. And I'd remind them they want to quit out i saw them smoking
I would help them realize the potential for a better healthier life
I would just offer as much moral support as possible. I would probably ask if it was okay to smoke around them, but I would at least try to be courteous about it.
I try to not smoke around them and encourage them.

Ask them, when they are in the quitting mindset, rather than the craving mindset, exactly how I can help, how they'd like me to behave around them in regards to smoking, and ensure they know that they can ask me to change that behavior around them at any time. If they want me to stop them, or just not give them smokes, I will hold them to it. Everybody's struggle is different, and it's important to work with someone rather than make assumption on what will work for them.
by not smoking round them giving them the temptation
2. What are some of your favorite qualities about yourself?  How does smoking fit (or not fit) with that image of you? #balance

Ugh- physically my teeth. They are my pride and joy, big white and rounded (from years of chewing my nails! Ew)  they make my face look... For lack of a better word normal.  Every day is a struggle to keep them white- creams, brushing, white strips, bananas- whatever it takes to keep them white from the amount I smoke #thestruggleisreal haha Non physically, I would have to say my sense of humor- it's dry and corny, witty and unique. One of a kind and genuine- when I find another with my sense of humor I'll know I'll have found my soulmate haha
Im an extremely friendly and nice person. Smoking does not effect that
I'm a people person. I can get along with just about anybody. I really don't think smoking fits anybody,
Yep
I'm a very kind and generous person I'll put the happiness and needs of others before my own even to the point of being sick

My work ethic is my favorite quality about myself. I truly believe in capitalism and the notion that you can achieve anything through hard work, even if you start from the bottom. That being said, I do kind of think that smoking plays into that in a way because working hard definitely generates some stress.
Even when things get really hard I just keep going and focus on the fact that things will get better. Smoking doesn't affect that.
the fact that once I get motivated to do something it gets done., whether it takes a bit longer than expected,, it gets done and smoking effects that in no way I believe

data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone and welcome to the group. On Wednesday, I will be holding the first "The Doctor Is In" session from 5-6 PM (Pacific Time). You can ask me everything you want to know around smoking, quitting, and the Tobacco Status Project.

data.message: Hey TSP members! We have decided to postpone our start date to this Friday. We apologize for the delay. Thanks for your patience and sit tight for two more days! :)
Start!
We aren't starting till Friday girl! Haha you only gots 1 mo day! Haha
Ive been ahead one day all week. Ugh
We really appreciate the enthusiasm and excitement!! :)
Hey
Haha, I guess I'm a little behind, considering its already Monday!

Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! Thank you for joining us -- we're so excited to have you here. We will start posting TOMORROW at 12 noon PST! Here's how it works:We will share one post everyday for 90 days. Remember to turn on your notifications and check this page daily!Your group has been randomly assigned to a Monthly Incentive. To earn money, you must comment on ALL posts we share each month (30 days). You will earn $30 if you've commented on all 30 posts, and $0 if you haven't. We'll tally your comments every 30 days, and you'll have a new chance to earn money at the start of the next month. You will receive a gift card for the money you've earned at the end of the 90-day program.Dr. Johannes Thrul will be joining us for 1 hour each week, during which he will answer any tobacco-related questions, share info and resources, and provide support to our group. Stay tuned for his first session next week!
Okay.
Go!
Go
Sounds good.

Hey group members! Our secret group is still growing, but the TSP program will be starting soon. Double check your notifications for this page and make sure they’re turned on (click “Notifications” in the upper right hand corner). Who's ready to get this show on the road?!
awesome,, I jus got added to this group,,
Welcome, 10301!

This group is for 18-25 year olds who smoke that want to learn more information about tobacco, how it affects your body, and the different quitting options available. Once you get more information about smoking and connect with other young adults who are in the same boat, you can decide if you want to make a change. Getting educated is the first step to making the right decision for YOU. This group has been randomly selected to have Monthly Incentives; you can accumulate $30 at the end of every month in which you comment every day, for a gift card of up to $90 at the end of the session.
